sources.title: The.Racketeer
sources.description: From IMDb : Tough mobster Mahlon Keane practically runs crime in New York City. He meets broke ex-society girl Rhoda Philbrooke at a society fundraiser and helps her cheat her way to some winnings in poker. Rhoda needs the money to help nurse broken alcoholic concert violinist Tony Vaughan back to health. In between his criminal dealings, Keane takes up Rhoda's cause and helps promote Vaughan's return to public performance. Rhoda agrees to marry Keane but still harbors unrequited love for Tony Vaughan. On the eve of her marriage, Vaughan confesses his love to Rhoda. Now how will she handle her mobster fiancÃ©e? Stars: Robert Armstrong, Carole Lombard and Hedda Hopper in a supporting role This movie can also be found here .

sources.title: The Racketeer (1929) | Colorized Public Domain Pre-Code Crime with Carole Lombard & Robert Armstrong
sources.description:
The Racketeer (1929) is an American Pre-Code crime drama directed by Howard Higgin and released by Pathe Exchange during the turbulent transition from silent films to talkies. This early sound-era feature blends romance, crime, and moral conflict while offering audiences a glimpse into the gritty realities of Prohibition-era America. Now beautifully restored and colorized by Colorized Public Domain, this edition brings new vibrancy to a rarely seen film that helped pave the way for later gangster classics.

Plot Summary:
Robert Armstrong stars as Knuckles Malone, a former gangster whose violent past and underworld connections cast a shadow over his attempts to live respectably. Despite his reputation as a racketeer, Knuckles is portrayed not merely as a ruthless criminal but as a man with humanity, loyalty, and hidden vulnerabilities.

Carole Lombard, in one of her earliest starring roles before becoming a screwball comedy icon of the 1930s, plays Rhoda Philbrooke, a struggling socialite desperate to regain her status. Out of financial hardship and personal desperation, she becomes entangled with Knuckles, forming a relationship that blurs the lines between survival, romance, and moral compromise.

As Knuckles faces betrayal, shifting allegiances, and the lure of crimeâ€™s easy money, his growing connection with Rhoda forces him to question whether redemption is possible. Their relationship unfolds in a tense and emotional atmosphere, portraying crime not just as spectacle but as a human struggle for dignity and second chances.

Cast and Crew:
â€¢ Director: Howard Higgin
â€¢ Writer: Charles Logue (adaptation), based on a story by Wallace Smith
â€¢ Cinematography: Ted Tetzlaff
â€¢ Production: Pathe Exchange

Starring:
â€¢ Robert Armstrong as Knuckles Malone
â€¢ Carole Lombard as Rhoda Philbrooke
â€¢ Roland Drew as Tony Vaughan
â€¢ Mathilde Comont as Olga
â€¢ Marie Prevost as Marjorie
â€¢ Albert Conti as Philip

Film Significance:
The Racketeer (1929) stands as an important transitional film in Hollywood history. Released at the dawn of sound cinema, it highlights the challenges studios faced adapting storytelling, acting, and cinematography to the new medium. It also belongs to the influential cycle of late-1920s crime dramas that foreshadowed the rise of the gangster genre in the early 1930s.

For Carole Lombard, this film was a stepping stone that showcased her dramatic potential before she reinvented herself as the queen of screwball comedy later in the decade with films like My Man Godfrey (1936) and Nothing Sacred (1937). Robert Armstrong, who would go on to star in the iconic King Kong (1933), brings toughness and pathos to the role of Knuckles Malone, a character who stands somewhere between criminal and tragic antihero.

The cinematography by Ted Tetzlaff (later known for his work on Notorious in 1946) adds visual weight, particularly in its moody depictions of urban nightlife, while Howard Higginâ€™s direction embraces the raw edge of early sound filmmaking.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
The Racketeer (1929) is in the public domain, meaning it can be freely shared, preserved, and reimagined without restriction. Colorized Public Domain restores this early talkie with enhanced visuals, cleaned-up audio, and thoughtful colorization, allowing audiences to rediscover a rarely seen Pre-Code gem. By reviving such films, we help preserve cinemaâ€™s history while making it more accessible to modern viewers across the USA, Europe, and beyond.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
As one of the first gangster-related dramas of the talkie era, The Racketeer benefits greatly from modern colorization. While its original black-and-white version captured the starkness of urban crime, the colorized edition brings new depth to its period costumes, lavish interiors, and atmospheric cityscapes. This presentation offers a fresh and immersive experience for contemporary audiences while maintaining the filmâ€™s historical integrity.

Each restoration ensures these cultural artifacts remain engaging and relevant for todayâ€™s audiences.

sources.title: The Racketeer (1929)
sources.description: I've been researching newly public domain films from 1929 and earlier, so I'm uploading the best possible copies that I can find. The Racketeer, also known as Love's Conquest in the UK, is a barely remembered early sound crime drama. Of note, it was banned in the UK before having nearly ten minutes edited out of it.Â  I have uploaded two versions of this film, as the higher quality version has a small watermark throughout. Otherwise, there is a lower quality version that does not have this watermark.Â  Watermarked version sourced from @CultCinemaClassics: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ijQh86m_2FA

Rhoda agrees to marry Keane but still harbors unrequited love for Tony Vaughan. On the eve of her marriage, Vaughan confesses his love to Rhoda. Now how will she handle her mobster fiancÃ©e?
